Ah, that's the million-dollar question, and I'm so glad you asked. Let me tell you—fostering self-growth and motivation isn’t about comfort zones, handouts, or special accommodations. It’s about tapping into the raw, unshakable power of the human spirit. I don’t believe in excuses. I don’t believe in limitations. I believe in the will to rise, to push forward, to overcome.

When I speak to an audience, I don’t sugarcoat it. I look them in the eye and say: You have everything you need within you. You just have to dig deep. If you're sitting there thinking, "But I was born with a disability," I say—so what? That’s not a reason to stop. That’s a reason to start. The truly able-bodied aren’t those who were born perfect. The truly able-bodied are those who rise above their circumstances, no matter what they are.

I teach my audience to reframe their mindset. Instead of asking, “Why me?” they should ask, “What can I do now?” Instead of waiting for the world to change for them, they must change themselves first. I tell them: You are the architect of your destiny. If your legs don’t work, build a mindset that makes up for it. If your hearing is impaired, let your will be so loud that it drowns out the silence.

Motivation? That comes from within. It’s not given. It’s earned. You don’t motivate someone by giving them a seat. You motivate them by showing them how to stand. And when they fall? They get up. And when they get up, they do it again. And again. Until standing is no longer a struggle—it’s a habit.

I don’t preach pity. I preach power. I don’t encourage dependence. I encourage determination. Because when people start to believe in their own strength, they become unstoppable. And that, my friend, is how you foster true self-growth.

Now, are you ready to rise? Or are you still waiting for permission?
